Erik Wilde (@dret): Starting the API Journey

(2) About Me

  • Ph.D. in Communications Systems [http://dret.net/netdret/publications#wil97b] from ETH Zürich [http://www.ethz.ch/] (1997)
  • Research at ETH Zürich [http://www.ethz.ch/] (1997-2006) and UC Berkeley [http://www.berkeley.edu/] (2006-2011)
  • EMC (2011-2014), API architecture for Documentum workflow products
  • Siemens (2014-2015), working on the Web of Things (APIs for IoT)
  • Part of CA [http://www.ca.com/]'s API Academy [http://www.apiacademy.co/] 2016-2019 focusing on API Design and Management
  • Partner at Good API [https://www.goodapi.co/] in 2019 focusing on Digital Transformation and API Strategy
  • Joined Axway [https://www.axway.com/]'s Catalysts [https://www.axway.com/services/catalysts] in 2019 for driving the Accelerate program [https://accelerate.axway.com/]
  • Active in the usual places such as Twitter [http://twitter.com/dret], GitHub [http://github.com/dret], and LinkedIn [http://www.linkedin.com/in/netdret]

Erik Wilde (@dret): Starting the API Journey

(4) The API Journey

  • Start: APIs are a necessary part of any digitalized business
  • API products are the building blocks of digital value chains
    • Business and IT need to be aligned to design and build value chains
    • Digital product teams should focus on the domain and build on a rich platform
  • Scaling the API practice is necessary on various axes
    • Speed: How long does it take to release an API?
    • Adaptation: How easily can we adapt/change products?
    • Evolution: How can the platform adapt to changing practices and needs?
    • Count: How easily can we deal with a large number of APIs?


Erik Wilde (@dret): Starting the API Journey

(5) Digital Transformation Challenges



Erik Wilde (@dret): Starting the API Journey

(6) APIs: Necessary but not Sufficient

  • Necessary: Good APIs are the plumbing for digital transformation
  • Not Sufficient: Digital transformation needs more than just APIs
  • Have a strategy, have a program, cultivate API mindset


Erik Wilde (@dret): Starting the API Journey
